Case 6-2
A Mature 12-Year-Old Who Refuses a Heart Transplant
Twelve-year-old Emma Ogden had suffered all her life from a congenital
heart defect that had led to over forty operations during her short life. Still,
she was not doing well. She suffered cardiac episodes periodically while
in school or at play leading to repeated calls to the emergency medical
services (EMS) personnel. Up to this point, they had always been able to
resuscitate her and transport her to the emergency room (ER) where eventu-
ally her condition was stabilized.
Now Dr. Abdul Hamid, the transplant surgeon at the hospital, had in-
formed Emma and her parents that her only long-term hope was a heart
transplant. The child's condition was so severe that she would not survive
much longer without the operation. Even with a transplant, her prognosis
was not good: no more than 10-20 percent chance of five-year survival with
likely repeated crises related to her damaged lungs and circulatory
system.
Emma was a remarkable child. She had recently been conducting
class sessions in school trying to help her classmates understand what
was happening when she would lose consciousness in school, leading to
rescue personnel rushing in and her fellow students being evacuated from
the classroom until she could be removed. She had written an essay pub-
lished in their local community newspaper describing her situation. The
teachers had told her parents that, in spite of her many missed school days
over the years, she tested three years above her grade level.
She had read everything she could find about her condition. She knew
her chances of survival were not good. She had had about all she could
take of hospitals, operations, and medical crises. After considerable
thought she came to the conclusion that the transplant was not worth it. She
knew the alternative was certain death in the near future. She had also
come to understand that an adult in this position would have the legal right
to refuse consent for the procedure. She told Dr. Hamid that she did not
want the transplant.
She had discussed the matter at length with her parents, who had re-
luctantly come to understand her position. They would support her if that is
what she wanted to do.
Dr. Hamid was taken aback. In all his years of cardiac transplant sur-
gery, he had never had a case like this one. Occasionally, an elderly patient
who was rapidly declining and had been advised that he or she was un-
likely to survive heart transplant had accepted his advice and declined the
extreme procedure, but never before had he been confronted with a refusal
by a 12-year-old who could potentially survive many years if everything
worked just right.
Dr. Hamid considered the possibility of getting consent from her par-
ents but realized that they might also refuse. He turned to an ethics com-
mittee, who explained to him that some adolescent minors were considered
sufficiently mature that they had the authority to make medical decisions
on their own behalf. (Some pregnant adolescents have consented to abor-
tion on this basis, for instance.) On the other hand, the committee members
had never invoked the mature minor rule on someone as young as 12 and
for a decision as momentous as a life-ending transplant refusal. Their al-
ternative was to treat her as other 12-year-olds, some of whom might ex-
press resistance to needed medical procedures. Parental consent is
normally acceptable in such cases. However, since the parents might
themselves refuse, his only option would be to seek a court order to oper-
_ ate against the wishes of both the girl and her parents. Should he accept
the girl's refusal, rely on the parents’ judgment, or attempt to get the court
order?

data.vignette: A 12-year-old with complex congenital heart disease has had dozens of operations and repeated resuscitated cardiac arrests. She is now in end-stage heart failure and cannot be discharged safely. The transplant team says a heart transplant is the only intervention that could extend her life, but it would mean another major surgery, lifelong immunosuppression, and a high chance of prolonged complications given her damaged lungs and circulation. The patient is unusually knowledgeable about her condition and consistently says she is “done” with invasive care and does not want a transplant. After many meetings, her parents agree to support her decision. A suitable donor heart may become available soon, and the team must decide whether to keep her actively listed. Hospital policy and state law allow either honoring a mature minor’s refusal or seeking judicial authorization for surgery in a life-threatening situation.
data.choice_1: Seek a court order and keep her active on the transplant list.
data.choice_2: Remove her from the transplant list and shift to comfort-focused care.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove language that makes transplant the clearly medically correct option. Edit “the only intervention that could extend her life” to something like “the main potentially life‑prolonging option being considered,” and add that prognosis with transplant is uncertain and may still involve significant morbidity. Also avoid implying inevitability by adding that comfort-focused care may align with goals and can include symptom-directed HF therapies without transplant.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim or tie background details to the ethical stakes. Replace “dozens of operations” with a concise, relevant summary (e.g., “multiple prior sternotomies and prolonged ICU courses”) and clarify current clinical status driving the decision (inotrope dependence/ventilation/ECMO candidacy, inability to leave hospital). Specify whether she is currently listed and at what status, and what ‘remove from list’ operationally means (change to inactive status vs delist).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify transplant feasibility details to avoid feeling clinically predetermined. Add whether she is medically eligible (e.g., transplant team has evaluated her, but lung vascular disease/adhesions make surgery high-risk; she is not on ECMO currently). Clarify that a 12-year-old can meaningfully participate but that decisional capacity is being actively assessed (psych/ethics consult), since capacity and prognostic uncertainty are central.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the ethically ‘easier’ path is to honor the patient/parents’ refusal; strengthen the competing rationale for seeking court authorization so both options remain defensible. Add factors like: concern she may have treatable depression/anxiety influencing refusal; intermittent delirium from low cardiac output/sedatives; parents’ agreement is recent/fragile; transplant team believes she could regain acceptable quality of life but with substantial burdens; and institutional precedent concerns about delisting a child who might later want transplant. Conversely, also articulate the harms of forced transplant (trauma, prolonged ICU, nonadherence risk) so the court-order option isn’t framed as a simple beneficence win.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the clinical framing so neither option looks medically/ethically obvious. Specifically: (1) Replace/soften language that makes transplant clearly futile or clearly the sole 'right' medical choice (e.g., change 'the only intervention that could extend her life' to 'the only potentially life-prolonging option, though outcomes and quality of life are uncertain'). (2) Remove or temper one-sided negative prognostic language such as 'a high chance of prolonged complications' and instead describe credible upside (a meaningful chance of months–years of survival with acceptable function) alongside serious burdens (major surgery, immunosuppression, possible prolonged ICU course). (3) Add a concrete, ethically weighty cost to honoring refusal beyond 'comfort care'—e.g., she is likely to die in the hospital soon without transplant, and clinicians worry they are abandoning a salvageable child. (4) Add a concrete, ethically weighty cost to pursuing court order beyond 'override'—e.g., she would need sedation/restraints to proceed with workup/bridging, will likely lose trust, and may experience significant suffering if the transplant course is prolonged. (5) Consider minimizing the legal-policy hook so the dilemma reads value-based rather than 'what does the law allow'; keep it as background and focus the choice on whether to treat her refusal as binding vs proceed despite it.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove value-laden phrasing that nudges toward refusal. Replace “dozens of operations,” “repeated resuscitated cardiac arrests,” and “done with invasive care” with neutral clinical descriptors (e.g., “multiple prior cardiac surgeries and episodes of cardiopulmonary arrest with ROSC”). Replace “only intervention that could extend her life” with “the only potentially life-prolonging option being considered.” Avoid “high chance” and instead use qualitative but balanced wording (e.g., “substantial risk of prolonged post-operative complications given pulmonary vascular disease”).

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use more standard clinical terminology and structure. Specify diagnosis category (e.g., single-ventricle/Fontan physiology) and current supports (inotropes, ventricular assist device candidacy, mechanical ventilation status) if relevant. Replace “resuscitated cardiac arrests” with “cardiopulmonary arrests with return of spontaneous circulation.” Replace “damaged lungs and circulation” with “pulmonary vascular disease/end-organ dysfunction.” Present as a concise consult-style summary.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the forcing context and decision point. Remove redundant intensity (“dozens”) and streamline to: current clinical status, transplant as option, patient/parents’ position, imminent donor availability, and legal/policy pathways. Clarify whether she is currently listed and whether delisting would preclude future relisting. Ensure the dilemma is framed as the physician’s decision (listing status) rather than an abstract “team must decide.”

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make choices parallel, neutral, and within ~10–15 words without embedded next-step care plans. Revise to: (1) “Maintain active transplant listing and petition court to authorize transplantation.” (2) “Deactivate transplant listing and continue medical management without transplant evaluation.” If comfort care is essential, keep it brief and parallel: “Deactivate listing and transition to symptom-focused care without transplantation.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the framing so transplant is not described as both the only life-extending option and also having a “high chance” of prolonged complications while comfort care is presented as cleanly aligned with everyone’s wishes. Suggested edits: (1) Replace “high chance of prolonged complications” with qualitatively mixed expectations (e.g., ‘significant risks of a prolonged ICU course, but some children with similar physiology recover and have meaningful years at home/school’). (2) Add ethically weighty costs to delisting (e.g., ‘she may die within days–weeks in hospital, and staff worry they are abandoning a salvageable child’). (3) Add morally weighty costs to overriding refusal beyond “court order” (e.g., ‘would likely require sedation/restraints for lines and pre-op care; could permanently damage trust; parents fear trauma’). (4) Avoid “dozens of operations” and “repeated resuscitated arrests” unless directly needed; they currently stack the deck toward refusal by implying suffering and futility.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, there are obvious middle options (inactive/on-hold listing, time-limited trial of continued listing while reassessing assent, enhanced palliative care alongside listing). To make the decision truly binary, explicitly close off these alternatives: (1) State that the donor offer is expected within a short window and the program requires an immediate decision: either remain ‘active/accept offers’ or be removed entirely; no inactive status permitted at this center for this circumstance. (2) Clarify that further deliberation is not feasible (e.g., she is losing capacity due to worsening heart failure or impending intubation). (3) Specify that ethics consultation has already occurred and the transplant committee will only accept one of the two dispositions today.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Current facts strongly imply a policy/procedural answer: transplant programs typically require the recipient’s voluntary agreement/participation; a patient who consistently refuses is usually not eligible to remain actively listed, making Choice 1 nonviable. To restore a true gray zone: (1) Clarify that the center’s transplant policy permits listing with parental permission even when an older child refuses, and the ‘assent’ requirement is discretionary rather than mandatory. OR (2) Make the patient’s stance less definitive (e.g., alternates between refusal and willingness depending on symptoms; accepts transplant if certain limits are honored), so guidelines don’t clearly dictate delisting. (3) Add that state case law is mixed and hospital counsel says either path is legally supportable, not merely ‘allowed,’ and that there is no clear professional consensus for this age/maturity level in this jurisdiction.

data.vignette: A 12-year-old with single-ventricle (Fontan) physiology is hospitalized in end-stage heart failure. She is dependent on continuous inotropes and cannot be discharged safely. The transplant service has deemed her medically eligible, but surgery would be technically difficult and could require a prolonged ICU course, mechanical support, and lifelong immunosuppression. Some children with similar disease recover and spend meaningful time at home and school after transplant. Others never leave the hospital. Over weeks of meetings, she has repeatedly said she does not want a transplant, although staff note intermittent confusion when her perfusion worsens and sedating medications are increased. Her parents now agree to follow her refusal but fear she may be traumatized if forced. A donor offer is expected within days, and this center requires a decision today: remain active and accept offers or be delisted entirely. Hospital counsel confirms either path is legally permissible here.
data.choice_1: Keep her actively listed and petition the court to authorize transplantation.
data.choice_2: Delist her from transplantation and continue care without transplant, focusing on comfort.

choice_1.choice: Keep her actively listed and petition the court to authorize transplantation.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating whether she has been formally assessed as having (or lacking) decision-making capacity/assent at baseline (e.g., ‘psychiatry deems she lacks capacity due to fluctuating delirium’ or ‘she is consistently able to understand and repeat back risks/benefits when not sedated’).

Add a clause quantifying expected benefit: e.g., “The team estimates transplant offers a high likelihood of meaningful 1–5 year survival and discharge home, whereas without transplant she is expected to die within weeks despite maximal palliation.”
Add a clause stating that without transplant she is expected to die soon (e.g., within days–weeks) with escalating symptoms despite inotropes, so delisting carries a high risk of imminent death.

Add one clause noting the donor heart is a scarce resource and that staying listed would likely mean another child is bypassed (e.g., 'accepting this offer would mean the organ is not available to another urgently listed child').

data.vignette: A 12-year-old with single-ventricle (Fontan) physiology is hospitalized in end-stage heart failure. She is dependent on continuous inotropes and cannot be discharged safely. The transplant service has deemed her medically eligible, but surgery would be technically difficult. It could require a prolonged ICU course, mechanical support, and lifelong immunosuppression. The team thinks transplant could allow discharge home and years of meaningful survival, but it could also lead to complications and prolonged hospitalization. Without transplant, cardiology expects death within days to weeks despite inotropes and symptom-directed care. She has repeatedly said she does not want a transplant. Child psychiatry finds she cannot consistently demonstrate understanding because her cognition fluctuates with low perfusion and sedating medications. Her parents now agree to follow her refusal but fear she may be traumatized if forced. A donor offer is expected within days, and this center requires a decision today: remain active and accept offers or be delisted entirely. Remaining listed would use a scarce donor heart that could otherwise go to another urgently listed child. Hospital counsel confirms either path is legally permissible here.

choice_1.choice: Keep her actively listed and petition the court to authorize transplantation.

choice_2.choice: Delist her from transplantation and continue care without transplant, focusing on comfort.

human_evaluation.comments: i don't think it's clear that delisting does not cause harm -- short vs long term vs interpretation. this is a good case because it's hard, just changed the one value.
